course_title: Biochemistry of Metabolism in Health & Disease

learning_outcomes.description: Analyse how changes in nutritional input affect metabolic processes in the body.
Evaluate, with reference to key clinical examples, how metabolic processes are integrated and controlled at the cellular, tissue, and systems levels.
Appraise the systemic impact of the normal and abnormal function of key organs and tissues in the setting of pregnancy, obesity, and metabolic disease.
Examine the central role of the liver in metabolism and the detoxification of noxious substances to protect cells from toxic environmental factors and metabolites.
Evaluate the role of the microbiome in the regulation of metabolism and assess microbiome changes in diseases with complex aetiologies.
Critically evaluate the multifactorial nature of metabolic diseases, including genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors.
Demonstrate familiarity with modern research techniques used in metabolic studies, including microbiome analysis and bioinformatics tools.
Communicate complex ideas effectively to diverse audiences using appropriate scientific language and formats and provide constructive feedback on the work of your peers.
Analyse, interpret, and present scientific data.

assessments.due_date:
RiPPLE Module 1 Converting Nutrients to Energy 8/08/2025 2:00 pm

RiPPLE Module 2 Storing Energy 22/08/2025 2:00 pm

RiPPLE Module 3 Integrated Metabolism 12/09/2025 2:00 pm

RiPPLE Module 4 The microbiome in regulating metabolism 10/10/2025 2:00 pm

RiPPLE Module 5 The Liver in Metabolic Distress 24/10/2025 2:00 pm

On the last Friday of each module at 2 pm, you have to have completed the UQ RiPPLE assignment.
assessments.task_description:
For each module, you have to complete the UQ RiPPLE assignment by the last Friday of the module at 2 pm. The RiPPLE assignment consists of:

  • Creating 1 question
  • Moderating 5 questions from your peers
  • Answering 10 questions

For each module you can receive a maximum of 2% of your course mark, which makes for 10% of your course mark for the full series of UQ RiPPLE assignments.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Complete the RiPPLE assignment in the UQ RiPPLE online environment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Xanthine Oxidase practical participation and analysis
assessments.task_description:
This assessment item has two components:

  1. An assessment of completion of each lab session (Pass/Fail).
  2. A scientific poster based on the analysis of the data collected in the laboratory sessions (real and virtual, 22.5%).


There are three (3) practical sessions and two (2) tutorial sessions for this assessment task; held in weeks 1-6 of the semester. ATTENDANCE OF THE PRACTICAL SESSIONS IS COMPULSORY. Practical: Determination of xanthine oxidase activity as detailed in the practical manual, additional experiments need to be conducted in the Virtual Laboratory environment. Analysis of real and virtual laboratory data will be discussed in the tutorial sessions for this practical. The results of the practical sessions, analysed as instructed in the tutorial sessions, have to be presented as a poster suitable for a scientific conference. The poster will be assessed on its own e.g. you are not required to do an oral presentation of the poster. Detailed guidelines and instructions will be provided on Blackboard.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 

Please read the following carefully:

1. If you are absent from a practical session:

You must attend and complete 100% of the laboratory component of this course. 

If you are unable to attend your timetabled practical session due to circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation that covers the date of the missed practical.

A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting information is found at: https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1

Requests for practical absences can be submitted via the course Blackboard site under the Assessment tab > Learning Resources > Practical Absence. Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation by the due date and time. Requests without correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered as absent form that practical session and the laboratory attendance hurdle may apply.

Extensions will not be granted for alternate assessment (unless exceptional circumstances can be demonstrated).

Alternate assessment will only be approved for one missed practical (unless exceptional circumstances can be demonstrated).

Do not apply for a practical absence for an extension to the submission of the associated assessment. Follow the procedure below.

 

2. If you require an extension on the assessment that you need to submit:

Follow the instructions listed under Deferral or Extension.

Do not apply for an extension for a practical absence. Follow the procedure above.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit a PDF of your XO poster through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard. Before submitting your assessment item to Turnitin please name your file in the following way. FAMILY NAME_GivenName_StudentID_CourseCode_AssignmentName For example: Bob Smith (ID: 54329876) would name his ABCD1234 essay 1 in the following way. SMITH_Bob_54329876_ABCD1234_Essay1
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment item has two components:

  1. An assessment of completion of the first computer practical session (Pass/Fail).
  2. An assessment of the computer practical report which is based on the analyses performed in the computer practical sessions.


High throughput DNA sequencing is a common method to analyse the bacterial community making up the gut microbiome. This practical is designed to provide students with a practical understanding of the workflow and complexities of microbiome analysis and to enable you to critically judge microbiome research that you encounter in other contexts. Students will analyse samples obtained from rodents with different health conditions and varying dietary intake patterns. As a result of these conditions, the composition of the microbiome changes and conclusions may be drawn about the relationship between the microbiome and metabolic health. Students will start with a table containing the abundances of bacteria in the microbiome and an accompanying mapping file that will be analysed with different statistical methods to identify features that are common and/or specific to various metabolic states. You will be guided through this process using a detailed manual.

ATTENDANCE AT THE FIRST OF THE TWO COMPUTER PRACTICALS IS COMPULSORY. If you have finished your analyses before the second practical and do not need the support from tutors for your assignment, you do not have to attend this practical. Please note that support will only be provided in the workshops.

Students will analyse these data individually and independently and then present these in an individual report that includes a detailed discussion of the results and biological/physiological interpretation. The report contains the results of the analyses done in the computer practical with additional questions on the interpretation of these results. The computer practical manual contains all the instructions on how to do the analyses as well as the interpretation questions that need to be answered.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 


Please read the following carefully:

1. If you are absent from a practical session:

You must attend and complete 100% of the laboratory component of this course. 

If you are unable to attend your timetabled practical session due to circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation that covers the date of the missed practical.

A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting information is found at: https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1

Requests for practical absences can be submitted via the course Blackboard site under the Assessment tab > Learning Resources > Practical Absence. Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation by the due date and time. Requests without correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered as absent form that practical session and the laboratory attendance hurdle may apply.

Extensions will not be granted for alternate assessment (unless exceptional circumstances can be demonstrated).

Alternate assessment will only be approved for one missed practical (unless exceptional circumstances can be demonstrated).

Do not apply for a practical absence for an extension to the submission of the associated assessment. Follow the procedure below.

 

2. If you require an extension on the assessment that you need to submit:

Follow the instructions listed under Deferral or Extension.

Do not apply for an extension for a practical absence. Follow the procedure above.

assessments.task_description:
This is a 120 minute examination covering the content of all modules. This will be an on-campus, invigilated exam.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 6(28 Jul - 07 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Xanthine Oxidase practical series and tutorials

Assay of xanthine oxidase activity. This is a series of 3 weeks of wet lab and virtual practicals. Alternative sessions available during week. Check SI-net for times and class sign-on. It is followed by two weeks of tutorials where the analysis of the data is discussed.
learning_activities.topic_description: Xanthine Oxidase practical series and tutorials Assay of xanthine oxidase activity. This is a series of 3 weeks of wet lab and virtual practicals. Alternative sessions available during week. Check SI-net for times and class sign-on. It is followed by two weeks of tutorials where the analysis of the data is discussed.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 2(28 Jul - 10 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 1: Converting Nutrients to Energy

Lecturer: Dr Justin Ridge The metabolism of carbohydrates, fats and proteins and the response to dietary input.
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 1: Converting Nutrients to Energy Lecturer: Dr Justin Ridge The metabolism of carbohydrates, fats and proteins and the response to dietary input.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 3 To Week 4(11 Aug - 24 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 2: Storing Energy

Lecturer: Dr Justin Ridge will deliver content on how excess energy is stored in the body in different forms. Examples of when this goes awry will be examined.
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 2: Storing Energy Lecturer: Dr Justin Ridge  will deliver content on how excess energy is stored in the body in different forms. Examples of when this goes awry will be examined.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 7(25 Aug - 14 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 3: Integrated Metabolism

Lecturer: Associate Professor Marloes Dekker will discuss the hormonal control and integration of metabolism. The impact of metabolic dysfunction focusing on obesity and diabetes as well as pregnancy will be discussed.
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 3: Integrated Metabolism Lecturer: Associate Professor Marloes Dekker will discuss the hormonal control and integration of metabolism. The impact of metabolic dysfunction focusing on obesity and diabetes as well as pregnancy will be discussed.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 13(08 Sep - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Exam training workshops

In these workshops (one in week 7 and one in week 13), you will sit with other students in groups to work through exam questions from past exams. Staff will be around to provide input and advice.
learning_activities.topic_description: Exam training workshops In these workshops (one in week 7 and one in week 13), you will sit with other students in groups to work through exam questions from past exams. Staff will be around to provide input and advice.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 8 To Week 9(15 Sep - 28 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 4: The microbiome in regulating metabolism

Lecturer: Dr Paul Evans will discuss the applications of modern research techniques to investigate the role of the microbiome in regulating metabolism
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 4: The microbiome in regulating metabolism Lecturer: Dr Paul Evans will discuss the applications of modern research techniques to investigate the role of the microbiome in regulating metabolism

learning_activities.topic:
Guest Lecture

Professor Emma Hamilton-Williams will provide a state-of-the-art lecture on the progress in our understanding of the interactions between the gut microbiome and type 1 diabetes. This lecture occurs during the Microbiome in regulating metabolism module.
learning_activities.topic_description: Guest Lecture Professor Emma Hamilton-Williams will provide a state-of-the-art lecture on the progress in our understanding of the interactions between the gut microbiome and type 1 diabetes. This lecture occurs during the Microbiome in regulating metabolism module.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 10 To Week 11(06 Oct - 19 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Microbiome-computer exercise

Dr Rix will oversee the Computer exercises in microbiome analysis. Alternative sessions available during week. Check SI-net for times and class sign-on.
learning_activities.topic_description: Microbiome-computer exercise Dr Rix will oversee the Computer exercises in microbiome analysis. Alternative sessions available during week. Check SI-net for times and class sign-on.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 12(13 Oct - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 5: The liver in metabolic distress

Dr Simon Worrall will discuss Specialised topics in metabolism: Review of hepatic metabolism; Alcoholic steatosis; and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease similar pathology but different aetiology. He will also discuss Oxidative stress and how cells deal with it (including biology of selenium); Specialised hepatic metabolism drugs & haem (including biology of iron).
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 5: The liver in metabolic distress Dr Simon Worrall will discuss Specialised topics in metabolism: Review of hepatic metabolism; Alcoholic steatosis; and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease similar pathology but different aetiology. He will also discuss Oxidative stress and how cells deal with it (including biology of selenium); Specialised hepatic metabolism drugs & haem (including biology of iron).
